entry.title: Hereâ€™s why white sneakers are actually pretty great travel shoes
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
Shoes are the biggest puzzle when it comes to packing. Whatâ€™s versatile, wonâ€™t take up too much space or bring your luggage over the weight limit? If youâ€™re not checking in a bag, choosing wisely is even more essential. The answer: A white sneaker.
That may sound surprising, but we love packing white sneakers for trips, as long as theyâ€™re properly prepped and maintained. â€œItâ€™s a great staple,â€ says New-York based freelance fashion director Sam Chadâ€¦

entry.title: How to travel like a local in Japan
entry.summary:
Travel experts recommend a relaxing, stress-free stay at a traditional Japanese inn or ryokan when visiting Japan. Itâ€™s a not-to-be-missed experience and a local favorite.  From subtropical islands to chilled-out ski resorts, there are so many places in Japan that don't suffer from the overtourism that's challenging more popular areas.
Japan is a deservedly popular destination, but travelers often wind up seeing the same sights and miss out on the far-flung, quieter, or less obvious corners of the country. To see a softer side of Japan, we asked locals, from writers to motorcycle enthusiasts, nonprofit workers to photographers, to share something about the places they love best.Â Travelers with only a day to spare should consider visiting Mount Takaoâ€”the most prominentâ€¦

entry.title: Everything you should know before visiting Japan
The 31 best Greek islands to visit in 2025
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
From the gastronomic isles of the Cyclades to the enigmatic ruins of the Dodecanese, each of the six main Greek island groups has its own distinct character. Yet, look closely and youâ€™ll find that more unites than sets them apart: there are secluded towns loved by local gourmands, hidden coves brimming with mythical associations and, above all, a natural splendour thatâ€™s captured the minds of artists and adventurers through the ages. Here are the best Greek islands to visit.
According to Greek mythology, it was Poseidon who seized a chunk of Kos and hurled it on top of a fiery Titan called Polyvotis â€” creating the volcanic island of Nisyros, with its enormous, sulphurous caldera. The volcano is active, but traveâ€¦

entry.title: How waves of immigration have created culinary magic in Tampa
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As I wander past the New Orleans-style iron verandahs, cigar shops and organic ice cream parlours on Tampaâ€™s palm-tree-lined 7th Avenue, I realise Iâ€™m being followed by a rooster. Like me, he seems to be heading to The Columbia â€” Floridaâ€™s oldest Spanish restaurant.
Itâ€™s a balmy November afternoon, and elderly gents and young people are shooting the breeze while smoking cigars in armchairs on the pavement, but nobody seems phased by my feathered friend. Here in Tampaâ€™s Ybor City neighbourhood, the rooster is king.
An official edict states the chickens must be allowed to roam free in honour of the areaâ€™s original Cuban immigrants, who raised the birds. Along with settlers from Spain, Italy, Germany, Switzerlandâ€¦

entry.title: Top 10 things to do in Japan
entry.summary:
Travelers should visit Senso-ji temple, Tokyoâ€™s oldest-established temple located in the cityâ€™s Asakusa neighborhood. It's just one of 10 things first-time visitors should do when exploring Japan. In a nation as culturally rich as Japan, it can be hard to know how to spend your time there. Here are ten of our favorite things to do.
Japan is an alluring destination because of its many juxtapositions. Neon skyscrapers tower over Shinto shrines, and salarymen ride the train next to Harajuku girls. The Land of the Rising Sun also has diverse climates and cultural attractions to please every style of traveler. Adventurers can ski Nisekoâ€™s slopes or hike Mount Fuji, while food lovers can eat their fill of street snacks in Osaka. Those seeking a more â€œZenâ€ vacation can relax in outdoor hâ€¦

entry.title: Why the equinox ushers in the arrival of spring
entry.summary:
Every six months, once in March and again in September, an equinox splits Earthâ€™s day almost in half, giving us about 12 hours of daylight and 12 of night.
On March 20, 2025, the vernal equinox will signal the coming of spring for the Northern Hemisphere. Then, in September, nature will once again bring us the autumnalÂ equinox, the time of year that ushers in fall in the North. Those dates are swapped for the vernal and autumnal equinoxes in the Southern Hemisphere.
(Here's why each season begins twice.) undefinedWhat are equinoxes? What causes these astronomical events? Find out how they influence the seasons and hours of daylight on each planet. Our planet normally orbits the sun on an axis thatâ€™s tilted 23.5 degrees, meaning that the hemispheres trade off getting â€¦

entry.title: Exposing Extremism Networks in Sub-Saharan Africa Using Open Source Tools
entry.summary: As extremism spreads across sub-Saharan Africa, journalists are turning to open source tools to track the networks and physical movement of these often violent groups.

entry.title: Tour the Indigenous southwestâ€™s living history on a road trip
entry.summary:
Monument Valley is a popular destination for American road trips. A new road trip of the Southwestâ€™s Indigenous heartlands offers travellers a greater understanding of the past, present and future of the countryâ€™s original inhabitants. Along the way, culturally sensitive tours with Native American guides explore ancient pueblos and impressive canyons.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Rain is pounding and the temperature is close to freezing. But the atmosphere inside the powwow tent at the Western Navajo Fair is electric. Here in Tuba City, Arizona, eagle feather headdresses and beaded buckskin skirts move to the beat of a drum. Green, yellow and blue ribbons flit through the air like parakeets. Dresses stitched with metal woosh like running wâ€¦

entry.title: How to spend the perfect day in Philadelphia's Fishtown
entry.summary:
Located in the cityâ€™s River Wards, Fishtown beams with an array of restaurants, bars and a vibrant art scene. Originally settled by fishermen, this ex-industrial neighbourhood is now one of Phillyâ€™s best days out.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Philadelphiaâ€™s riverside neighbourhood of Fishtown has seen a resurgence over the past decade as its inventive restaurants, dive bars and quirky stores draw visitors from near and far. The former fishing village, which morphed into an industrial powerhouse on the Delaware River, remains a blend of narrow streets of tall townhouses and repurposed warehouses, and retains its sense of community and tradition amid its modern developments.
Many people come to Fishtown solely for the restaurants, andâ€¦

entry.title: Is this America's greatest LGBTQ+ city break?
entry.summary:
From the pool to the cocktails, drag queen Trixie Mattel's motel has a thing for pink. This liberal, Californian desert town has reputation as one of Americaâ€™s greatest LGBTQ+ destinations, cemented by the opening of a motel run by a drag queen. Hereâ€™s how to spend a fun-filled 48 hours in its thrall.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
â€œWelcome to Palm Springs,â€ says Rosemary Galore, towering above me in six-inch skyscraper heels. â€œOr, as I like to call it, Gay Disneyland!â€ undefined undefined Itâ€™s a sleepy Sunday morning in the Californian desert city of Palm Springs and the sun is languidly rising above the jagged San Jacinto Mountains. Just beyond the window of the Saguaro hotel, palm trees sway lazily in the breeze and thereâ€™sâ€¦

entry.title: Meet the LGBTQ+ pioneers of Provincetown and Salem
entry.summary:
Itâ€™s rare for a hotel to have hosted four US presidents. Rarer still for it to also have a queer nightclub in its basement â€” where, during its weekly underwear parties, revellers check not only their coats but most of their clothing into the cloakroom on arrival. But Gifford House in Provincetown isnâ€™t your average hotel. Itâ€™s the jewel in the crown of a town that prides itself on having one of the highest concentrations of same-sex households in the US.
Presidents including Theodore Roosevelt visited Provincetown when it was the last stop on the stagecoach line. Over the years, other arrivals have included whalers, sailors and artists, who have come to settle on a shoreline edged with windswept sand dunes and saltbox houses. By the 1960s it was attracting LGBTQ+ tourists, offering a â€¦

entry.title: Where to see the worldâ€™s brightest bioluminescent tides
entry.summary:
The phenomenon requires warm, calm and windless waters, as well as low-lit new moon nights, to ensure particularly memorable displays. Watching phytoplankton illuminate the world's shores is an otherworldly experience. With a bit of luck and perseverance, these are the best places to catch the notoriously elusive natural phenomenon.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It only takes the gentle brush of a hand or slow glide of a boat to trigger the sparkling blue-green light of bioluminescent plankton, or phytoplankton. The dinoflagellates â€” single-celled phytoplankton that produce oxygen in water â€” emit a sparkling cold light when agitated as a protection mechanism.
This unpredictable category of glowing marine life, however, is known to playâ€¦

entry.title: How this â€˜Megalodonâ€™ goldfish got so huge
entry.summary: Corey Ketchum of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife service holds a giant goldfish found during a survey in Presque Isle, Pennsylvania. The service then posted a warning about releasing petstore goldfish on social media. Goldfish possess genetic traits that allow them to swell up to four poundsâ€”the size of a Chihuahua. Experts say that's why you shouldn't release them into the wild. Thinking about freeing your pet goldfish from their tank and letting them loose in a local pond or lake? Â Please donâ€™t, begs the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service in a recent social media post. In just two years, that harmless fish you know as â€œMr. Bubble Guppyâ€ can turn into an ecosystem-wrecking leviathan. Â â€¦

entry.title: Dedicated hikers say these are the best hiking boots for men
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*
Avid hikers know that finding the right hiking boots can mean the difference between a great adventure and a painful trek. Whether you're scaling mountain trails, braving wet and muddy conditions, or looking for reliable all-day comfort, choosing the right pair is essentialâ€”and weâ€™re here to help.Â
There are several key factors to consider when shopping for the best hiking boots, many of which boil down to personal preference and the kind of hiking â€¦

entry.title: This Mexican health spa helped shape modern wellness travel
entry.summary:
Before sunrise, I shuffled into a gazebo, clutching a weak cup of coffee and a portioned banana chunk, joining 15 other guests bundled up against the desert chill. After briefly learning about the 5-mile trail ahead of us, the other hikers suddenly bolted forward in a mad rush for the mountain. Welcome to Rancho La Puerta, where the day begins with gusto at dawn.
At this Tecate, Mexico, wellness resort, guests are encouraged, if not explicitly instructed, to join daily early-morning hikes during their week-long stay. As avid hikers (my husband Scott and I had recently completed the 10-day Tour du Mont Blanc in the Alps), we expected a leisurely pre-breakfast walk that aligned with the resortâ€™s ethos of mindfulness and tranquility. When our fellow hikers sprinted for the hills, we wereâ€¦

entry.title: The shaky science behind trendy â€˜super greensâ€™ powders
entry.summary:
Supplements known as "super greens" or "greens powders" claim to help reduce stress, improve digestion, and boost energy. But experts say there's little credible science to back it up. An occasional scoop of these crushed-up vegetables likely wonâ€™t do any harm. But experts say the benefits of these supplements are far from proven.
Itâ€™s hard to argue with the allure of a greens powder. Inside these pleasantly packaged tubs and pouches, youâ€™ll allegedly find an elite combination of crushed-up fruits and vegetables thatâ€™ll boost your energy, keep you regular, lower stress, and transform you into a more optimized version of yourself. Just mix a daily scoop of these â€œsuperâ€ greens into your bottle of water or morning shake and glug it down.
Greens powders are hardly a new concept: â€¦

entry.title: Why you should consider freezing your carbs before eating them
entry.summary:
Cooking, freezing, and reheating carbs like rice and potatoes creates resistant starchâ€”altering carbs in a way that can help control blood sugar levels. If you want to prevent blood sugar spikes and keep your energy levels steady, throwing foods like white rice or pasta into the freezer before eating them can help.
If youâ€™ve ever felt that mid-afternoon energy crash after a high-carb meal, or noticed that eating white rice or potatoes makes you hungrier faster, thereâ€™s a reason for that.
Carbs with a high glycemic indexâ€”like white bread, potatoes, and white riceâ€”break down too quickly into glucose and cause blood sugar spikes, which lead to a quick burst of energy followed by a crash. Knowing which carbs have a high glycemic index can help control your blood sugar. But freezinâ€¦

entry.title: Carolina the giant rat retires as a hero after saving many lives
entry.summary:
Carolina, an African giant pouched rat, recently retired from her job of detecting tuberculosis cases medical tests had missed. Last year, African giant pouched rats like Carolina prevented nearly 400,000 new cases of a deadly disease. It's possible because of their extreme sense of smell.
Until recently, Carolina worked Monday through Friday, with weekends off.Â Â Â
At her retirement this past November, colleagues lined up to applaud her and celebrate over cake. In her seven-year career, she had detected more than 3,000 cases of tuberculosis that health clinics had missed and, as a result, likely spared more than 30,000 other people from infection.Â
But she's not exactly your typical employee. Carolina is an African giant pouched rat who can screen 100 sputum (i.e phlegm)â€¦

entry.title: The surprising connections between diet and mental health
entry.summary:
Fermented vegetables like kimchi are thought to bolster your mood by improving your gut microbiome. They do so by populating your gut with healthy bacteria that balance out the bad bacteria. Research shows that certain foods really can help with depression and stress. Hereâ€™s whyâ€”and which foods help most.
Youâ€™ve undoubtedly heard the adage that you are what you eat. It turns out that it may apply to brain health nearly as much as physical health. Research increasingly supports the idea that eating the right foods and avoiding the wrong ones may improve your mood and emotional well-being over time.
â€œJust as we recognize that diet plays a role in conditions like heart disease or diabetes, we now understand that food choices can affect brain function, mood, and mental health disoâ€¦

entry.title: PSA: Never pick up a wild animalâ€”especially a baby wombat
entry.summary:
While wombats may appear cute and cuddly, they can be incredibly dangerous, and it's best to keep a distance from them in the wild. A video has been circulating of a woman taking a baby wombat from its mother. Hereâ€™s what experts want us to know about the dangers of interfering with wildlife, even if it seems innocuous.
Most people know not to come between a mother grizzly bear and her cubs. But what about a mother wombat and her wombatlet?
Wombats are short, squat marsupials native to Australia. And if youâ€™ve seen them in the news as of late, itâ€™s because American tourist and social media influencer Sam Jones posted a video of herself snatching a wombat joey away from its mother. Jones proceeded to run down a dark road with the frightened creature.
While the influencer â€¦

entry.title: No food deliveries to Gaza as border closures continue
entry.summary: The UN emergency food relief agency has not been able to transport any aid into the Gaza Strip, due to the ongoing closure of all border crossing points, which is now in its twelfth day, the UN Spokesperson said on Friday.

entry.title: Iran protests: Human Rights Council probe condemns online, app-based repression
entry.summary: The Iranian Government has continued to ramp up efforts to restrict the rights of civilians including young children as part of a concerted effort to crush dissent, investigators mandated by the UN Human Rights Council said on Friday.

entry.title: This stunning rail trail offers a different way to explore the Adirondacks
Cortisol rises during intense workouts. Is that a bad thing?
entry.summary:
Fitness influencers claim intense workouts such as HIIT or running can spike cortisol and hinder weight loss, while gentler alternatives like walking keep it in check. But cortisolâ€™s role in exercise is far more than simply â€œgoodâ€ or â€œbad.â€
Often branded as the â€œstress hormone,â€ cortisol is blamed for everything from belly fat to burnout. But it plays a crucial role in keeping the body running. â€œIf we donâ€™t have cortisol, we die,â€ says Martine Duclos, an endocrinologist and physiologist in sports medicine at UniversitÃ© Clermont Auvergne. It helps mobilize energy, suppress inflammation, and maintain blood pressure in stressful situations.
So, if cortisol is essential, why does it have such a bad reputation? And does exercise send it spiraling out of control? Hereâ€™s what the sciencâ€¦

entry.title: Discover the surprising cuisine of this Guatemalan town
entry.summary:
Livingston is not an island, but it exists so separately from the rest of Guatemala that locals use the word â€˜mainlandâ€™ to mean everywhere beyond its boundaries. Triple-isolated on the east coast by rainforest, river and saltwater, this small fishing town is cut off from the national road network and only accessible by boat. It used to be the countryâ€™s main seaport on the Caribbean, but that role shifted south east long ago to the larger Puerto Barrios, at the far end of Amatique Bay, and Livingston has been somewhat cut adrift.
I arrive hungry, on a small charter vessel, via the river mouth of the RÃ­o Dulce. The captain recommends Happy Fish, a wooden bar and restaurant that looks like a Wild West saloon, perched on the pier where he ties up the boat. At dusk, he tells me, it becomesâ€¦

entry.title: Everything you need to know about Nowruz, Persian New Year
entry.summary:
Nowruz celebrations in Baku usually include street festivals. Persian New Year is celebrated in many countries across the world. Hereâ€™s everything you need to know, including what to cook and where to celebrate.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The United Nations has marked 21 March as International Nowruz Day, commemorating a holiday that sees millions around the world eating, dancing and furiously spring-cleaning the house from top-to-toe. Nowruz, meaning â€˜new dayâ€™ in Persian, falls on the first day of the Persian calendar (around the same time as the Spring Equinox), and observes the end of darkness and the rebirth of nature. Hereâ€™s the 101 on a celebration thatâ€™s withstood multiple conquests and the test of time.
Nowruz, the Persianâ€¦

entry.title: These crocodile mummies are unraveling a mystery
entry.summary:
The teeth are well preserved on one of the crocodile skulls from the tomb at Qubbet el Hawa. After discovering a trove of mummified crocodiles in Egypt, researchers noticed something unexpectedâ€”these reptiles had an unusual embalmment.
In 2019, while excavating the necropolis of Qubbet el Hawa, across the Nile from Aswan in southern Egypt, Belgian and Spanish archaeologists unearthed a trove of mummified crocodiles: five almost complete skeletons, plus five heads.
Although crocodiles are often found in Egyptian tombs, it is rare to discover 10. The findings, published in the journal PLOS One, shed light on the embalming technique used and even how the animals might have died.
Egyptians saw crocodiles as intermediaries between humans and Sobek, the crocodile-headed god ofâ€¦

entry.summary: The analysis in this report is based on a self-administered web survey conducted from Sept. 18 to Oct. 10, 2024, among a sample of 1,391 dyads, with each dyad (or pair) comprised of one U.S. teen ages 13 to 17 and one parent per teen. The margin of sampling error for the full sample of [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Teensâ€™ future plans and goals
entry.summary: Given the current gender gap in college completion and the growing share of adults who donâ€™t want to have children, we were curious about teensâ€™ long-term goals and plans for adulthood.Â Plans after high school When we asked teens what they plan to do after they finish high school, 53% said they plan to attend [â€¦] The post 4. Teensâ€™ future plans and goals appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Pressures teens are facing
entry.summary: In addition to asking about the problems their peers at school are dealing with, we asked teens about the pressures they personally face. By far the biggest source of pressure for teens is their grades. Roughly seven-in-ten teens (68%) say they face a great deal or fair amount of pressure to get good grades. Substantial [â€¦] The post 2. Pressures teens are facing appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Teensâ€™ friendships and emotional support networks
entry.summary: Friendships play a large role in many teensâ€™ lives. Relationships with friends can also be a predictor of long-term outcomes for teens, including the quality of their adult relationships and work performance. We asked U.S. teens a few questions about their friend networks, and more specifically, whether they can turn to these networks for emotional [â€¦] The post 3. Teensâ€™ friendships and emotional support networks appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Problems teens see in their schools
entry.summary: We asked U.S. teens how common a variety of problems are among students at their school. Anxiety and depression tops the list, with 30% of teens saying itâ€™s extremely or very common at their school. About one-in-five teens (22%) say bullying is extremely or very common at their school. A similar share (19%) say the [â€¦] The post 1. Problems teens see in their schools appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: The Gender Gap in Teen Experiences
entry.summary: Teen girls and boys in the U.S. face different pressures and report different experiences at school, though they have many of the same goals in life. The post The Gender Gap in Teen Experiences appeared first on Pew Research Center.

Our stories illuminate serious issues that often go unexplained or underreported, such as sexual harassment and assault, broken promises to LGBTQ vets, and disinformation and extremism. We are seeking an Investigative Reporter to [â€¦]

entry.summary: Sudan is now the worldâ€™s largest and most devastating humanitarian crisis, the head of the UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) warned on Thursday. After two years of war, over 30 million people â€“ more than half of them children â€“ are living in the grip of mass atrocities, famine and deadly disease.

entry.title: Why Germanyâ€™s Camino trek rivals Spainâ€™s famous pilgrimage
entry.summary:
Travelers should consider the pilgrimage along the less-crowded St. James Way and other connected routes in Germany. It allows pilgrims and hikers an opportunity to see small-town sights, including this historic bridge in Vacha, which separated East and West Germany until the fall of the Wall. The bridge also marks the end of the pilgrimage route along the Regia River, from GÃ¶rlitz to Vacha. The Camino de Santiago is more than just one 500-mile route through Spain. Hereâ€™s why you should consider hiking the German section of trails.
In Spain, aÂ record-breaking number of pilgrimsÂ have attempted the Camino de Santiago (or the Way of St. James), turning the once contemplative pilgrimage or secular hike into a popular tourist attraction. An increase in hikers on the trail means travelerâ€¦

entry.title: Drinking chlorophyll is a popular wellness trend. Does it really work?
entry.summary:
If you regularly follow wellness and fitness influencers on social media, youâ€™ve likely seen afew videosof someone praising chlorophyll water and its purported benefits. Even the visual of adding a chlorophyll supplementâ€”usually sold as a liquid tinctureâ€”into a large glass of water is dramatic and alluring:a dark, concentrated cloudthat eventually dissipates, revealing a vibrant emerald tonic.
Promises of clearer skin, fresher breath, less bloating, and more energy are enticing enough to turn chlorophyll water into one of todayâ€™s top health trends. But does it actually do anything?Â
(5 things you should know before trusting that supplement.) Natural chlorophyll is found in green fruits and vegetables like spinach, broccoli, and kiwi. Chlorophyll supplements are typically sâ€¦

entry.title: Why your next trip to Mexico should be one of these festivals
entry.summary:
Altars in the historic city of Oaxaca are a spectacular sight during the DÃ­a de los Muertos celebrations. With a packed calendar of raucous street parties, traditional carnivals and centuries-old ceremonies, thereâ€™s no bad time to visit this Latin American country.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Day of the Dead may be Mexicoâ€™s most famous festival, but itâ€™s just one of 5,000 that take place in the country each year. These celebrations blend the culture of pre-Hispanic Mesoamerica with rituals brought by their Catholic colonisers: some are devoted to God, others to the devil; some celebrate life, others death. Processions form to mark everything from saints to particular professions, and no event is too small â€” even a girlâ€™s quinceaÃ±era, or 1â€¦

entry.title: This city is home to some of the best surfing in the U.S.
entry.summary:
Santa Cruz is an incredibly popular destination for surfers of all levels, and multiple surf schools offer classes every day of the week here. With rugged beauty and consistent waves, Santa Cruz is a surferâ€™s paradise. Hereâ€™s where and when to get your board in the ocean, and how to respect the marine wildlife.
Walking along Santa Cruzâ€™s East or West Cliff Drive, beyond the ocean spray and steep cliff walls, you'll most likely find dozens of wetsuit-clad surfers straddling their boards waiting for the next great wave. This California city is the birthplace of mainland surfing in the United States. Legend has it that in 1885, three Hawaiian princesÂ introduced the sport here â€” even convincing a lumber mill to create boards out of the local redwood. Santa Cruz remains famous for consiâ€¦

entry.title: This common infection is actually an STI
entry.summary:
For decades, bacterial vaginosis (BV) has been treated as a frustrating but routine infectionâ€”one that afflicts nearly a third of women in the U.S. and often comes back again and again for more than half of patients. But what if the reason for these relentless recurrences isnâ€™t just a quirk of the vaginal microbiome?
A groundbreaking new study suggests BV isnâ€™t just an imbalanceâ€”itâ€™s sexually transmitted. And the key to stopping it may not lie in treating women alone but in treating their male partners as well.
â€œOne dominant risk factorâ€¦ in our clinical studies was a regular partner,â€ says Catriona Bradshaw, an author of the study and a clinician at Melbourne Sexual Health Centre at Monash University. â€œ[It] kept popping out and just smacking us between the eyes, and we got to a pâ€¦

entry.title: Why Nowruz is a celebration of springtime
entry.summary:
Marking the beginning of a new year, Nowruz traces its origins back to ancient Persia. Today, the holiday is widely celebrated across the Iranian diasporaâ€”including these Iranian-Americans dancing at the 2016 Nowruz Festival in downtown Chicago. Nowruz, also known as Persian New Year, has been observed for more than 3,000 years as the victory of spring over darkness.
For the Northern Hemisphere, March 20 is the first day of spring. But for 300 million people around the world, itâ€™s the beginning of a new year, too. Nowruzâ€”which means â€œnew dayâ€â€”is a holiday marking the arrival of spring and the first day of the year in Iran, whose solar calendar begins with the vernal equinox.
Nowruz has been celebrated in Iran and the Persian diaspora for more than 3,000 years. Its roots are asâ€¦

entry.title: Best places to see cherry blossoms in the U.S.
entry.summary:
Cherry blossoms ring the Tidal Basin and Jefferson Memorial during spring in Washington, D.C.

Here's when and where to see these delicate pink and white flowers across the country. Since the introduction from their native Japan in the early 1900s, blossoming cherry trees signaled seasonal change in the United States. Bred for blooms and not for fruit, varieties like Yoshino, Kwanzan, and Akebono explode in a showy spectacle of delicate pink and white flowers for around two weeks each year. The downy blooms blanket parks, gardens, and towns in a visual transition away from the harsh chill of winter and toward the growing warmth of longer days. The tradition of cherry blossom festivals in the U.S. dates to 1935 in Washington, D.C. Thatâ€™s when the National Cherry Blossom fâ€¦

entry.title: Who made these unusual ancient â€˜puppetsâ€™?
entry.summary:
Clay figurines unearthed in El Salvador may be puppets whose poses sent a message to observers thousands of years ago. Described March 5 in Antiquity, some of the figurines have moveable heads with expressive faces, and they may contain hints about the unknown people who created them.
â€œTheyâ€™re actually amazing,â€ says Jan SzymaÅ„ski, an archaeologist at the University of Warsaw in Poland and a coauthor of the study. The three largest figurines are about one foot tall and are naked and bald.
In 2022, SzymaÅ„ski and his colleagues found the figures at San Isidro, a steep site among fields of sugarcane and coffee, at the top of an earthen mound that may have once been a pyramid. As they meticulously removed layer after layer of earth, they found the first figurine lying face down. Workâ€¦

entry.title: Saturn now has a ridiculous number of moons
entry.summary:
In recent years, Saturn and Jupiter have been in a moon race of their own. In 2019, Saturn took the lead with 20 new natural satellites, bringing its tally up to 82. Then Jupiter surged ahead to 92 in 2023. And later that year, Saturn reached 146, leaving Jupiter in a respectable second place position with 95.
But this week, Jupiter has truly been left in the dust. Astronomers have just announced the detection of an additional 128 moons, brining Saturnâ€™s total to an eyewatering 274.
â€œThis is a stunning increase in the number of known moons orbiting Saturn, a number which is always hard to keep up with,â€ says James Oâ€™Donoghue, a planetary astronomer at the University of Reading in England and who was not involved in the new discovery. â€œJupiter is now very much in the rear-view mirâ€¦

entry.title: 11 womenâ€™s slip-on shoes for sailing through airport security
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
Nothing beats slip-on sneakers when youâ€™re facing a long line at airport security or when youâ€™re running late for a tour. These days, thereâ€™s no shortage of options, but itâ€™s important to find a pair that balances ease with good support and comfort.Â
To help travelers find the right pair of slip-on shoes, we analyzed top-rated options and spoke with footwear expert Yash Mehta, a spine and sports medicine specialist in Virginia. Our top pick, the Kiâ€¦

entry.title: The â€˜Black Angelsâ€™ cared for TB patients when no one else would
entry.summary:
Nurse Blanche Newton gives Alfred Maddox Isoniazid medication at Sea View on Feb. 2, 1952. In the early 20th century, these Black nurses came to New York City from the Jim Crow South to join the fight against the diseaseâ€”and they ultimately helped find a cure.
Virginia Allen was just 16 years old when she joined the nursing staff at Sea View Hospital in New York City, a facility that opened specifically to address the millions dying of tuberculosis, also called â€œconsumptionâ€. At the time, the highly contagious illness was poorly understood and many white healthcare workers refused to help.
Allen was one of the thousands of Black nursesâ€” the â€œBlack Angelsâ€â€”who stepped up, joining her aunt Edna Sutton Ballard at the Staten Island hospital.Â
It was a â€œrich work experience [aâ€¦

entry.title: Discover Cataloniaâ€™s adventure playground
entry.summary:
In the Val dâ€™Aran â€” where the Pyrenees meet France in northwest Catalonia â€” things get pretty wild. Nature runs riot here, with snow-frosted granite mountains rising above fir-cloaked slopes, glacier-carved valleys and piercing blue lakes. The highest peak, 9,875ft MoliÃ¨res, towers above forests where brown bears roam and rivers flow ferociously all the way to the Atlantic. Hike, bike, raft, canyon, ski, snowshoe or stargaze â€” no matter the time of year, opportunities for adventure are aplenty.
Val dâ€™Aranâ€™s mountainous interior is also home to some of Spainâ€™s most picturesque villages, which provide an insight into the regionâ€™s rich history and Occitan heritage. You'll hear snippets of the area's own official language, Aranese, as you weave between romanesque churches and flower-drapeâ€¦

entry.title: 6 ways to explore Hong Kong's adventurous side
entry.summary:
A common sight in Hong Kong's residential district of Quarry Bay are the tightly packed buildings. It may be best known for its skyscrapers and shopping, but Hong Kong offers untold outdoor activities, from coastal kayaking and mountain hikes to quiet bike rides and unusual food tours.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Corralled byÂ mountain, sea and great swathesÂ ofÂ protectedÂ countryside, HongÂ KongÂ canÂ appearÂ as incongruous as it is remarkable. Around 600 skyscrapers face off across the narrow glint of Victoria Harbour â€” roughly a third more than Manhattanâ€™s tally. Like densely packed trees fighting for light, this forest ofÂ glass and steel strains ever-skywards: urban sprawl on a vertical plane. Through the canyons and warrens created far beloâ€¦

entry.title: â€˜Anxiety, paranoia, fearâ€™: The consequences of digital violence against women
entry.summary: Online attacks against women are getting worse, according to the UN, causing lasting damage that can spill over into real world violence. Leading activists from Spain and Latin America met at UN Headquarters on Wednesday to rally women and share strategies on fighting back.

entry.title: Humanitarian system at breaking point as funding cuts force life-or-death choices
entry.summary: The UNâ€™s top relief official warned on Wednesday that the global humanitarian system has reached breaking point, with funding cuts forcing life-or-death decisions over which aid programmes to sustain and which to shut down.

entry.title: Human Rights Council: Significant increase in child victims of trafficking
entry.summary: ChildrenÂ make up almost four in 10 victims of trafficking worldwide, but the true number of youngsters caught up in the illegal practice is likely much higher, a senior UN official warned on Wednesday.

entry.summary: The United Nations is prioritising reform to ensure it remains effective, cost-efficient and responsive to the people it serves, Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres announced Wednesday, as part of a continued push to modernize the Organization.

entry.title: Afghanistan: Opium prices approach historic peaks, crime syndicates benefit

entry.title: Veteran Environmental Journalists Offer Tips on Covering the Second Trump Administration
entry.summary: Covering Trump 2.0 poses stark challenges for news outlets, but many environmental journalists who reported on Trump between 2016 and 2020 can offer perspective.

entry.title: Cycle this epic section of the new Great American Rail-Trail
entry.summary:
Palouse Falls is one of many sites that can be visited by travelling the Great American Rail-Trail. The Great American Rail-Trail will cross the entire country when completed, but one of the most epic sections has already opened in Washington state.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It takes but a minute to put wheels in motion for one of the greatest adventures you can have in America, yet nearly three months to experience it in full. Running from Washington State to Washington, DC, the 3,700-mile Great American Rail-Trail moves from Pacific waves and old-growth forests at its western end to the White House and the Capitol in the east.
Its east-west spine is made up of abandoned rail corridors that morph into urban greenways. Along the waâ€¦

entry.title: Unraveling the mysteries of the worldâ€™s most critical rainforest
entry.summary:
Within the dense canopy of the Congo Basin Rainforest, the afternoon light began to fade, glinting off a soaring metal tower that rose steeply out of the jungle. Measuring 180 feet tall, the narrow steel structure resembled a massive cellular-network antenna, although it was outfitted with a collection of far more critical scientific sensors. The wind had picked up, causing the spire to sway and whine with each strong gust. But a biologist named Fabrice Kimbesa appeared undaunted. After strapping into a safety harness, he grabbed hold of a thin metal ladder and clambered briskly upward, leaving me to catch up as he raced toward a small platform at the very top.
This particular structure is whatâ€™s known as an eddy covariance flux tower. When it came online in October 2020, it became thâ€¦

entry.title: These fish swam with the dinosaurs. They may not survive us.
entry.summary:
The white sturgeon is the largest freshwater fish in North America; it can grow upwards of 15 feet. Here, in Idahoâ€™s Snake River, state fishery officials tag an eight-footer. For 162 million years, sturgeons have fended off everything theyâ€™ve faced. Now scientists are racing to save these living fossils.
The river flows vast andÂ soundless. Itâ€™s December in southern Kazakhstan, and the landscape near the Syr Darya River is smudged in shades of brown and taupeâ€”dormant grasses, silted floodplains, leafless trees. This is not the most picturesque stretch of riverbank, strewn as it is with food wrappers, bottles, a decomposing sedan. Overhead, the sun is obscured by a haze of coal- and woodsmoke. But when it comes to what Bernie Kuhajda is searching for, the spot feels perfect.
â€œThâ€¦

entry.title: The stunning power of whale pee
entry.summary:
For too long, Humpback whales' urinary contributions to the ocean have been overlooked. A single whale can produce more than 250 gallons of urine in a day. It helps sustain life across the ocean.
In the deep blue water, a one-month-old humpback whale nuzzles up to its mother. Then, a cloud of dark yellow urine gushes into the water, like a golden smoke bomb, and everything becomes tinged with green.Â
This footage provides a new clue to an important ingredient for a healthy ocean: whale wee. Â
Scientists have spent a lot of time thinking about how the nutrients in whale fecesâ€”also known as whale pumpâ€”benefit species in shallow waters, as whales swim up from the deep sea, where they feed, to poop near the surface.
But they had overlooked another important nutrient souâ€¦

entry.title: The ultimate guide to the 2025 Jubilee in Rome
entry.summary:
Pope Francis opened Saint Peter's Basilica's holy door for Jubilee 2025, the Catholic's holy year, at the Vatican on Christmas Eve 2024. More crowds than usual are expected this year in the Eternal City. We explain what the Jubilee is, how to navigate the crowds, and what to see and do while there.
A trip to Rome is an exhilarating experience at any time. But with the Catholic Churchâ€™s Jubilee currently hitting its stride, 2025 is gearing up to be an even bigger year than usual.
The Jubilee is expected to draw more than 30 million visitors to the Eternal City, which has spent billions of euros cleaning up its monuments and upgrading its transport networks in preparation for the event. People are already starting to trickle in, so if youâ€™re planning to come later in the year, bâ€¦

entry.title: A â€˜blood moonâ€™ total lunar eclipse is comingâ€”hereâ€™s when to watch
entry.summary:
People gather to watch a â€œblood moonâ€œ eclipse in Melbourne, Australia, on July 28, 2018. On March 13-14, 2025, skywatchers across North America will have a prime view as the Moon turns red during a total lunar eclipseâ€”the first visible in the region since 2022. Skywatchers across the world will witness the first total lunar eclipse in three years. Hereâ€™s who will have the best viewsâ€”and what gives the moon its eerie red tint.
For the first time since 2022, skywatchers across North America will see the full moon slip into Earthâ€™s shadow, transforming into a deep reddish hue. The event begins after midnight on March 14 in the eastern U.S. and Canada, while those in the western half of the continent will see it unfold before midnight on March 13. Hereâ€™s what causes this phenomenon andâ€¦

entry.title: Can this graphic novel change America's views on climate? It did in France.
entry.summary:
Jean-Marc Jancovici is a rare specimen: a climate and energy nerd who is also something of a rock star. In the early 2000s, the French author and engineering consultant devised a carbon accounting system that is now widely used by companies in Europe to track their greenhouse gas emissions. Around the same time, he began giving lectures on climate change, videos of which went viral in France and eventually attracted the attention of Christophe Blain, a graphic novelist, who invited Jancovici to collaborate on a book.
Le Monde sans Fin, published in October 2021, explains Jancoviciâ€™s overarching theses: why fossil fuels will not be easy to abandon, and why and how we must do so anyway. It became the single bestselling book in France in 2022, ultimately selling more than a million copieâ€¦

entry.title: Why sleep tourism is the latest travel trend to know about
entry.summary:
Londonâ€™s Kimpton Fitzroy offers a Room to Dream package that focuses on lucid dreaming. Across the world, resorts and retreats are using the latest technology alongside holistic practices to create dedicated sleep-improving programmes.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Scrolling through social media over a morning coffee, youâ€™re just as likely to see someone sharing their sleep tracker data as a sunrise yoga session or breakfast smoothie. Amid the so-called sleep epidemic â€” in the UK, 74% of adults report sleeping badly, and research suggests that 5-7% are seeing their GP to complain about fatigue â€” a solid eight-hour sleep has become a sought-after luxury and something weâ€™re all keen to shout about. With travel and wellbeing so intrinsically iâ€¦

entry.title: WHO injects fresh support into DR Congo vaccination drive
entry.summary: The UN World Health Organization (WHO) has stepped up efforts to improve vaccination coverage in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) by providing vital logistical support, including boats and motorcycles to reach remote communities along the Congo River.

entry.title: Women still face inequalities, despite the 19th Amendment
entry.summary:
Women line up to vote for the first time in New York City in 1920, after the passage of the 19th Amendment. Women won the right to vote more than a century ago, but access to the ballot has never been equal. Learn about the barriers faced during the suffragist movement.
It included just 28 words, but a single sentence transformed the civil rights of women in the United States. It was Article I of the 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, and it guaranteed that â€œThe right of citizens of the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of sex.â€ Passed by Congress on June 4, 1919 and made into law in August 1920, the amendment gave women political power over 130 years after the nationâ€™s founding.
It was the culmination oâ€¦

entry.title: 9 things to know about Holi, Indiaâ€™s most colorful festival
entry.summary:
A kaleidoscopic cloud hangs over India, where revellers mark the arrival of spring by throwing powdered dye with abandon, spraying water, and flooding the streets for raucous fun. Holi may be traditionally Hindu, but everyone is equal during this holiday. This year on March 14, color will hide all class lines, the caste system will disappear, and foreigners will join the locals.
Underneath the dancing and colorful chaos lies unique culture and deeply rooted tradition. Hereâ€™s what you need to know about Holi.
The colorful party makes up just one part of Holi. The night before, on Holika Dahan (the evening of bonfires), revelers set a symbolic effigy ablaze to commemorate the demise of the demoness Holika. People throw the famed, colored powder on Rangwali Holi, the second and moâ€¦

entry.title: Where to taste the best of Vermontâ€™s maple syrup
entry.summary:
It takes 40 gallons of tree sap to create one gallon of maple syrup. The formula might come from science, but the result is pure magic, especially to Vermonters, whoâ€™ve been tapping and sugaring in the Green Mountains longer than the stateâ€™s existed.
The stateâ€™s sole outpost of IHOP, which closed in 2024, was the only branch in the country to serve real maple syrup. In part, this is because state law strictly prohibits labeling any product maple â€” or even â€œmaple flavoredâ€ â€” if it doesnâ€™t contain pure maple syrup. But more importantly, serving fake maple syrup would put a thumb in the eye of Vermont pride.Â
As such, any traveler seeking the full Vermont experience must travel through maple country. And the closer you can get to the sugarhouse, the purer the experience. Visitorâ€¦

entry.title: What was Manhattan like in the Roaring Twenties? See for yourself
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Itâ€™s been a century since The Great Gatsby was first published, shining a light on extravagant New York lifestyles in an era that went down in history as the â€˜Roaring Twentiesâ€™. It was the decade that paved the way for Manhattanâ€™s Chrysler Building and other progressive style icons, creating an anything-goes atmosphere for jazz-fuelled parties, Champagne afternoons and secret affairs in Prohibition speakeasies. And, 100 years later, itâ€™s still possible to experience this defining spirit in one ultimate day out in New York City.
(It's the 100th anniversary of The Great Gatsby and New York is ready to party, old sport.)
Time travel back to 1922 with a hearty breakfast at the Square Diner, an original train-carâ€¦

entry.title: How to spend a week sailing around Greece's Ioanian islands
entry.summary:
Meganisi is renowned for its sea caves. A week aboard a yacht, with the help of a local skipper, makes for the ultimate sailing adventure around Greeceâ€™s Ionian Islands.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
â€œReady to tack?â€ a voice shouts. Before I can ask what that means, the sails flicker and the entire boat suddenly tilts sideways. Dishes and bowls of fruit crash against each other inside the cabin. I grab hold of the railing and laugh nervously, but the smiles on my crewmatesâ€™ faces reassure me that this is a good manoeuvre. Moments later, we catch the wind and weâ€™re off. Apostolis Tsiokos, our tanned,silver-haired skipper, is humming along to We Are Sailing by Rod Stewart.
The 52ft monohull yacht, Neifinn, can accommodate up to 11 crew mâ€¦

entry.title: Women, girls bear brunt of cyberbullying against persons with disabilities
entry.summary: States must do more to prevent cyberbullying and overcome unequal access to assistive technology which hampers the rights of persons with disabilities - particularly women and girls - the Human Rights Council has heard.

entry.summary: Severe water shortages in Gaza have reached critical levels, with only one in 10 people currently able to access safe drinking water, the UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) warned on Monday.

entry.summary: Gender equality is a critical goal at a time when the demand for rights faces a global backlash, top UN officials told thousands of diplomats, business and civil society delegates gathered at UN Headquarters in New York on Monday for the worldâ€™s largest annual conference focused on womenâ€™s issues.

entry.summary: Children are feared to be among more than 1,000 people reportedly killed in fierce fighting over the weekend in Syriaâ€™s coastal northwest, the UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) has said.

entry.title: A practical guide to travelling in southern Mexico
entry.summary:
The historic centre of Oaxaca City is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. To get the best value, helpful booking tips and language lowdown, try this handy guide. 
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Â Central America is home to undisputed wonders. Its cultural attractions span ancient Maya sites, colourful 16th-century cities and Indigenous markets, while its landscapes cover active volcanoes, Caribbean beaches and tracts of jungle that are home to unique birds and big cats. Yet, for the most part, it's remained out of the international tourist trail, which means planning a first-time trip here can be somewhat intimidating.Â Â
The short answer is no. Without a visa, you can visit Belize for up to 30 days; Costa Rica for up to 180; and Panama â€¦

entry.title: Why the way to travel Oaxaca's Pacific Coast is on two wheels
entry.summary:
Playa Zicatela is a world-renowned big-wave beach. A short stretch of Oaxacaâ€™s scenic Pacific coast makes an easy day trip from Puerto Escondido â€” plan on plenty of pit stops, whether youâ€™re exploring via two wheels or four.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Thereâ€™s a word in Spanish, â€˜arrebolâ€™, which doesnâ€™t have a satisfactory English translation. Itâ€™s used to describe a crimson sunset, when each cloud on the horizon acquires a halo-like glow and the skyâ€™s amber tint grows fainter as the sun slides into the sea. Such a sight would be a rarity in England, but on Mexicoâ€™s Pacific coast itâ€™s a nightly occurrence. An arrebol accompanies bedtime on my first night in Puerto Escondido â€” in this stylish party town, Iâ€™m probably the only person turninâ€¦

entry.title: Maybe megalodon wasnâ€™t so chonky after all
entry.summary:
This illustration of megalodon may be wrong. The ancient predatory shark went extinct around 3.6 million years ago and has been compared to modern great white sharks. However, new estimates suggest that megalodon had a slimmer, longer body.  A new study proposes that the massive ancient shark was built more slenderly than a great white. But not all paleontologists agree.
Close your eyes and imagine the ancient, abominable megalodon.
Youâ€™re probably picturing a great white shark scaled up to gargantuan proportions, right? Well, a new study suggests the worldâ€™s largest-ever shark may have been longer and more svelte than once thought.
â€œPrevious studies simply assumed that megalodon must have looked like a gigantic version of the modern great white shark without any eviâ€¦

entry.title: Explainer: The Commission on the Status of Women and why it matters
entry.summary: Ever since former US First Lady and human rights champion Eleanor Roosevelt inspired the first UN sub-commission on the status of women in the 1940s, thousands of women around the world meet at UN Headquarters in New York every March to take the pulse of the planet and make their voices heard.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraine reels from one of the deadliest days of war
entry.summary: Attacks across Ukraine on Friday reportedly left 21 civilians dead and scores injured, making it one of the deadliest days this year, the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in the country said in a statement issued on Saturday night.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights chief raises alarm over escalating violence in Syria
entry.summary: The killing of civilians in coastal areas in northwest Syria must cease immediately, the UN rights chief said on Sunday following a series of coordinated attacks reportedly launched by elements of the former government and other local armed men.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: A guide to Å ibenik, Croatiaâ€™s oldest coastal town
entry.summary:
On the central coastline of Dalmatia, where the River Krka winds its way to the Adriatic Sea, lies Å ibenik. For those in the know, the city provides a relaxed blend of history and natural beauty. Itâ€™s home to two UNESCO Heritage sites â€” more than anywhere else in Croatia â€” and has long attracted TV and film producers who have made use of its honeyed stone streets, grand old buildings and dramatic natural setting. Journey through Å ibenikâ€™s history, explore dramatic fortresses and sample traditional Dalmatian cuisine on a city break here in 2025.Â
While many other settlements on this stretch of coastline were founded by Romans, Greeks or other invading forces, Å ibenik was founded by Slavs at least as early as 1066 AD and, as such, is considered the oldest Croatian town on the Adriaticâ€¦

entry.title: 100 years after Gatsby, New York is reliving the Roaring Twenties
entry.summary:
The Chrysler Buildingâ€™s spire is an iconic Art Deco addition to New York City's skyline. A hundred years after The Great Gatsby shone a light on extravagant Long Island mansions and secret speakeasies, the spirit of the Roaring Twenties is returning to New York.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Itâ€™s late morning in Harlem and the jazz brunch at Mintonâ€™s Playhouse is in full swing. Cocktails are flying out across the polished mirrored bar, as up on stage a spotlit singer croons over an Ella Fitzgerald number. Behind her are framed photos of the jazz greats who once jammed at this legendary nightclub, including Billie Holiday and Dizzy Gillespie. To glance around the low-lit room, filled with chatter and jive, feels like stepping into New Yorkâ€™sâ€¦

entry.title: How female rappers are making their mark in America's Music City
entry.summary:
Rapper Mia Reona was raised in Nashville's African-American Jefferson Street district. In Americaâ€™s country music capital, a new generation is stepping out from the shadows of its beloved honky-tonks. Meet the trailblazing female rappers singing â€˜Music Cityâ€™ a different song.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Itâ€™s early evening in Nashville and classic country music drifts from the doorway of a nearby honky-tonk bar. Peeking inside the dingy dive, I see a four- piece band in matching western-wear owning the stage. Their rhinestone costumes dazzle under the spotlights as they serenade the crowd, who look amped for a night of serious two-stepping. For me itâ€™s too early to start line dancing, so I continue strolling along Lower Broadway â€” commonlyâ€¦

entry.title: What's healthier: fresh or frozen produce?
entry.summary:
Despite the reputation frozen produce has for being unhealthy, studies show it's better than we think. Since frozen produce is picked and preserved at its peak, it can sometimes be considered more nutrient dense while also cutting down on food waste.
While frozen produce often gets a bad rap, research shows it can often be just as healthyâ€”if not healthierâ€”than fresh produce.
In a study comparing the nutritional content of fresh and frozen corn, carrots, broccoli, spinach, peas, green beans, strawberries, and blueberries, researchers found that the vitamins in frozen produce are "comparable to and occasionally higher" than their fresh counterparts. Other studies have corroborated the idea that the only major nutritional difference between frozen and fresh produce is when refrigâ€¦

entry.title: Waterproof backpacks may be the perfect travel bags
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
A damp park map, a soaked granola bar, a fried laptopâ€”thereâ€™s nothing worse than water seeping into your travel gear. The only reliable way to keep your valuables dry in wet conditions is to store them in a waterproofâ€”as opposed to a water-resistantâ€”backpack.Â
â€œWater-resistantâ€ typically means the productâ€™s exterior has been treated with a finish like Durable Water Repellent (DWR) coating. That offers partial protection from light rain or brief moiâ€¦

entry.title: A robot taught these birds a long-lost birdsong
entry.summary:
The song of the male chingolo, or rufous-collared sparrow (Zonotrichia capensis), is one of the most distinctive sounds in South America. In just a few seconds, this small birdâ€”light brown or whitish with black spotsâ€”delivers its melody, composed of two to four introductory notes and a final trill. Each family of chingolos has its unique song, which they sing throughout their lives. But first, they must learn it.
This behavior is deeply rooted in the interaction between young and adult male chingolos, who transmit the patterns of their song. But what happens when this learning is interruptedâ€”when habitat loss, population decline, or the disappearance of adult tutors break the chain of transmission?
(Huge decline in songbirds linked to common insecticide.)
Between 2020 and 20â€¦

entry.title: Take a healing dip in UK's most historic spa towns
entry.summary:
Romans used Bath's hot spring to build a bathing complex in 43 CE. From local tribes worshipping a water goddess to Romans settling in areas with natural springs, Englandâ€™s history of spa towns stretches further back than vacationing Victorians seeking to cure their ailments. Hereâ€™s how to explore some of the countryâ€™s most historic spa towns and experience the natural spring waters yourself.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Next time you swig some British spring water, take a moment to ponder where it came from â€” maybe Harrogate, Malvern or Buxton? From the late 1700s, English towns with nearby springs were transformed into spa destinations, becoming magnets for those who believed these waters could cure everything from scabies to smallpox. Tâ€¦

entry.title: The unexpected wine country you need to visit: New Mexico
entry.summary:
The Rio Grande Valley is one of New Mexicoâ€™s most prolific winemaking regions. Hispanic and Native American wine producers cultivate vineyards at high altitude and on desert plains in this southwestern state, making for some unique cellar-door visits.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Framed by the Sangre de Cristo Mountains in the north and the Chihuahuan Desert in the south, the USâ€™s fifth-largest state is a land of rolling sand dunes, prehistoric petroglyphs, fairytale caves and dormant volcanoes. Equally as diverse as the topography is the culture, which reflects the history of the Indigenous, Hispanics and Anglo Americans who have coexisted in New Mexico for centuries. Youâ€™re most likely to first encounter this diversity through the cuisiâ€¦

entry.title: Where to travel in April
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK)
April is the month where there's all to play for. The Med is back in action for sun and coastal fun, putting short-haul escapes to the beaches within easy reach once again, while the last of the Alpine snow keeps winter sports lovers entertained for just a bit longer. In most resorts across the Alps, the ski season closes this month, with some high-octane, high-altitude festivals to see it out â€” among them Zermatt Unplugged in Switzerland, which brings nearly 70 different artists to the mountains.
Further afield, Thai new year celebrations see its cities making a splash, Coachella kicks off the summer's music festivals out in the California desert and travel is enriched by Easter celebrations worldwide.
In moreâ€¦

entry.title: Do dogs hate daylight saving time too?
entry.summary:
With daylight saving time starting this month, dogs and their owners will likely lose an hour of sleep, as clocks are set forward. And if youâ€™ve ever wondered if domesticated dogs have as much trouble adjusting to the time change as humans do, it turns out, scientists have looked into this question.
Â In 2021, researchers in Ontario, Canada, conducted a study of both sled dogs and companion dogs during fall daylight saving time, when we gain an hour and see an earlier sunrise. Both dogs and their human owners or caretakers wore sensors (on their collars and wrists, respectively), which measured movement and activity.Â Â
The scientists found while the pets had no trouble with the change, it took the sled dogsâ€”working canines who were housed outdoors in kennelsâ€”a day to adjust.Â This â€¦

entry.title: 10 family-friendly things to do in Texas
entry.summary:
Visitors enjoy a star party at the McDonald Observatory in Fort Davis, Texas. Itâ€™s just one of 10 things families should add to their kid-friendly itinerary when visiting the Lone Star State. Feel tiny under the big Texas sky, marvel at an annual bat migration, travel on horseback through a colorful canyon, and soak in sublime hot springs.
Larger than any country in Western Europe, Texas sprawls across more than 268,000 square miles that touch Mexico, the Gulf of Mexico, and four U.S. states. The Lone Star State is so vast and diverse in its landscapes and cultures that it can feel like a wondrous country all its own. Wherever you land to kick off your family adventures hereâ€”whether an urban metropolis like Dallas-Fort Worth, Houston, or Austin, or somewhere altogether more off theâ€¦

entry.title: 10 family-friendly hotels in Texas
entry.summary:
Families visiting Dinosaur Valley State Park in Glen Rose should consider staying nearby at the hotel, La Palmilla. Itâ€™s just one of 10 recommended family-friendly hotels to stay when visiting Texas.  Looking for a hotel that keeps both adults and kids in mind? These options across the state offer on-site water parks and bike trails, or easy access to nearby river cruises and dinosaur tracks.
Interactive museums and street art. Hiking and horseback riding. Dinosaur tracks and early settlements. These Texas hotels give adults and kids easy access to all the state has to offer. And with on-site pools, tennis courts, and even TopGolf simulators, itâ€™s more than okay to just hang out on the property, too.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â
Overlooking the famous River Walk, the 338-room, Spanish Coloniâ€¦

entry.title: Why itâ€™s unlikely Mount Vesuvius really turned a brain to glass
entry.summary:
In the ruins of Herculaneum, an Ancient Roman city on the west coast of Italy that was buried by Mount Vesuvius's catastrophic eruption in 79 A.D., researchers made a startling discovery: a human brain transformed into glass. It was the first documented case of a brain naturally preserved in such a shocking state.Â
The remains were found inside the skull of a seemingly male victim lying in a charred bed withinÂ the Collegium Augustalium, preserved in what the researchers describe as an "obsidian-like" material with a black, shiny appearance.Â
But exactly how the eruption would have caused such an unprecedented transformation remained a mystery when the ancient victim was found.
Now, the same scientists who discovered this glass, have published a study in Scientific Reports saâ€¦

entry.title: Millions in Central Sahel and Nigeria face food cuts amid WFP funding crisis
entry.summary: The UN World Food Programme (WFP) warned on Friday that potentially life-saving food and nutrition assistance in Central Sahel and Nigeria will have to end next month, unless emergency funds can be secured.

entry.title: Post-Assad Syria faces critical test over eliminating chemical weapons
entry.summary: The fall of the Assad regime has created a historic opportunity to rid Syria of chemical weapons and ensure long-term compliance with the Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC), the UNâ€™s top disarmament official told the Security Council on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria: Up to one million people plan to return home in desperation
entry.summary: Up to one million desperate Syrians living in camps and displacement sites across the countryâ€™s northwest intend to return home within the next year â€“ sparking deep concerns of a new humanitarian crisis.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo crisis leaves mothers with newborns fleeing to Burundi
entry.summary: The aid response in Burundi to the crisis in neighbouring Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) â€œis literally bucklingâ€, the UN refugee agency, UNHCR, warned on Friday, as it relayed dramatic testimonies from people forced to flee the unchecked advance of Rwanda-backed M23 rebels.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Online â€˜manosphereâ€™ is moving misogyny to the mainstream
entry.summary: A decline in democracy and harmful content spread on social media platforms are helping to drive a backlash against feminism, and the growth of misogynistic and retrograde ideas about the roles of men and women and society.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: WOMEN'S DAY LIVE UPDATES: â€˜Rights are not negotiableâ€™ â€“ Sade Baderinwa
entry.summary: International Womenâ€™s Day, observed on 8 March, is about challenges, backlashes against gender equality and cause for celebrations around the world. Join us as we cover events, changemakers and celebrities at UN Headquarters and beyond today. UN News app users can follow here.

entry.title: The hidden meaning behind Rome's famous arch monuments
entry.summary:
Temples functioned as sites of worship, and the Colosseum served as an amphitheater for games and spectacles. But triumphal archesâ€”such as the Arch of Constantineâ€”were remarkable for being among the few purely symbolic buildings erected by the Romans. With their decorative sculptures, reliefs, and inscriptions, these monuments provide a wealth of historical sources to researchers, and their excellent state of preservation has secured them pride of place in the collective memory of many generations of scholars, travelers, and politicians interested in the ancient Roman Empire.
The triumphal arch originally grew out of the triumphal parade, a ceremony integral to life in the Roman Republic. These lavish processions through Rome were a way for generals and their soldiers to celebrate theâ€¦

entry.title: The best wineries on the Gran Canaria Wine Route
entry.summary: Gran Canaria might not be the first place you think of when it comes to wine, but vines have been growing here since the Spanish colonised the island in the 15th century. Due to the island's distinctive microclimate and volcanic soils, grapes grow incredibly well, and the Canarian archipelago lays claim to 18 unique grape varieties, including the famous MalvasÃ­a AromÃ¡tica â€” featured in some of Shakespeareâ€™s famous works. Though red varieties make up about 70% of Gran Canaria's wine production, connoisseurs should keep an eye out for local white, rosÃ©, sparkling and sweet wines, too. The best way to sample them? By taking to the trail on the Gran Canaria Wine Route â€” the only official wine route in the Canary Islands â€” which includes vineyards, bodegas, bars and restaurants that produce or â€¦

entry.title: Hoping to ski until July? Here are 7 places to go in the U.S.
entry.summary:
At Alyeska Resort in Alaska, the northern lights can sometimes be seen through April. These resorts keep the lifts spinning late into the season, providing access to some of the best springâ€”and summerâ€”skiing in North America.
It is typical to crave a tropical destination when trying to survive the last few months of winter, but skiers know that springtime is the best-kept secret in the sport.
With fewer crowds, soft snow, and long aprÃ¨s-ski afternoons spent in the sunshine, this is the best time of year to be on the mountain. The intensity of chasing mid-winter powder days has subsided, and the celebratory spring atmosphere brings a new energy.
Pack your sunscreen and warm-weather wax and get ready to enjoy the last few turns of the season. From longtime skiers to familieâ€¦

entry.title: 1 in 5 butterflies in the U.S. have disappeared
entry.summary:
Researchers compiled data on more than five hundred butterfly species across the United States from 2000 to 2020. Some species are faring better than others, but overall, butterfly numbers dropped by 22 percent.  Researchers identified over 100 species that have dropped by more than 50 percent in the last two decades: "This is a wake-up call."
In the last 20 years, one in five butterflies have disappeared in the United States.
According to a landmark study published today in the journal Science, total butterfly abundance in the U.S. has declined by 22 percent across all species between 2000 and 2020.Â
â€œThis is a wake-up call. People should be seeing this number and being very, very concerned, not just about butterflies, but about the state of insects in general,â€¦

entry.title: Darwin couldn't find these fabled horses. They've reappeared.
entry.summary:
A genetic mutation causes the Argentine Criollo horse to grow curly hair. The mysterious curly coated horses in South America evaded the famed naturalist. But now one couple is forming a herd of their ownâ€”and trying to save the species.
There, in a desolate corner of the SomuncurÃ¡ Plateau in the Argentine province of RÃ­o Negroâ€”where the word â€œinhospitableâ€ seems to have been inventedâ€”Gerardo RodrÃ­guez, a veterinarian, spotted a horse calmly grazing amid the rugged landscape. Seeing any horse in such an isolated, arid region was already unusual, but this one was unlike anything he had ever encountered: Its coat was curly.
Initially, RodrÃ­guez thought the horseâ€™s curly coat indicated it was sick or sweaty, but a gaucho, or horseman, told him something surprising: These curly-haiâ€¦

entry.title: Where to try the food on â€˜No Taste Like Home with Antoni Porowskiâ€™
entry.summary: Actress Issa Rae and No Taste Like Home host Antoni Porowski sit with Mama Yacine, Fatima Fall, Papa Abdoulaye Sene, and Hamade Ndiaye to eat ceebu jÃ«n, also known as thieboudienne, a Senegalese dish made with fish, rice, and tomato sauce. These traditional family recipes each tell a story about ancestral heritage. Here's how you can try each oneâ€”from tortellini en brodo in Italy to jajangmyeon in South Korea. InÂ National Geographicâ€™sÂ seriesÂ No Taste Like Home with Antoni Porowski, six Hollywood stars follow the Queer Eye star on a journey through food and time as they travel through their ancestral homelands in search of family history. Starting with just one homemade family recipe, Porowski helps stars Awkwafina, Justin Theroux, Issa Rae, â€¦

entry.title: Follow in Malcolm X's footsteps on a civil rights history tour in Boston
entry.summary:
West Acorn Street in Beacon Hill takes travellers along the Black Heritage Trail. Itâ€™s 100 years since the civil rights activist was born. Follow in his footsteps on a tour of Bostonâ€™s suburbs, where his legacy lives on.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Malcolm Xâ€™s birthday will be recognised as a new annual holiday in Boston this May. Though born in Nebraska in 1925, the civil rights activist lived in the Massachusetts city on and off for 12 years during a pivotal â€” if controversial â€” era in the fight for African American rights in the US. The formative years he spent in Boston â€” becoming a leading Muslim minister here before his assassination at a New York rally in 1965 â€” have left a lasting legacy that can still be seen in the cityâ€™s monumeâ€¦

entry.title: 10 of the best hotels in Salzburg, Austria
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The most Austrian of cities, Salzburg is an instant heart-stealer. Itâ€™sÂ backdropped by the MÃ¶nchsberg, a mount rising like a gentle giant above the old townâ€™s alleys and abbeys, plazas and palaces. Topping it is a 900-year-old fortress straight out of a kidsâ€™ story, while the mountains on the horizon remind you that the Alps are but a yodel away. The hotel scene mirrors the city itself: petite, characterful and surprisingly varied, skipping from revamped medieval inns to affordable palace stays. If youâ€™re visiting, book now: in 2025, Salzburg will celebrate 60 years of The Sound of Music with performances, exhibitions and tours of filming locations. Rooms in Hotel Schloss MÃ¶nchstein hold an antique and whimsical câ€¦

entry.summary: Global efforts to tackle the HIV/AIDS epidemic continue to remain insufficient, with deadly consequences, the UN Human Rights Council heard on Thursday.

entry.title: Why This Colombian Investigative Reporter Had to Wait Over a Decade to Tell a Story
entry.summary: Ginna Morelo put part of her investigation into Colombian paramilitaries on hold for 13 years to protect her family and sources. She tells how she decided it was finally time to publish.

entry.title: Iâ€™m a stroke survivor. These tools make travel easier.
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
I love exploring new places and enjoying adventures with family and friends. However, as a stroke survivor with autoimmune diseases as well as assorted back and leg issues, mobility considerationsâ€”sometimes accompanied by muscle aches and/or joint painâ€”are a part of my daily life. I also experience frequent vertigo that can make me lose my balance or fall. These are all factors I must consider when planning a trip.Â Â
Additionally, I help care for, â€¦

entry.title: Why March is Women's History Month in the U.S.
entry.summary:
Women have always been part of history. But for centuries, their participation in it was overlooked: Early history texts often excluded women altogether, aside from accounts of powerful women like queens. Historiansâ€”who were almost entirely menâ€”often saw the past through the lens of the â€œgreat manâ€ theory, which holds that history is largely shaped by male heroes and their struggles.
That changed in the 20th century, with the birth of womenâ€™s history as an academic discipline, a push to recognize the achievements of womenâ€”and a movement to ensure women had equal access to the academic institutions where their history might be taught. In the United States, the result was National Womenâ€™s History Month, an annual celebration born from the activism of historians intent on making sure womâ€¦

entry.title: The best way to experience Alpine culture? Eatâ€”and drinkâ€”it
entry.summary:
Harsh temperatures and unpredictable high-altitude soil have strengthened the roots of the Alps, and the farmers living there are as resilient as the food they grow. Here, people have survived the unimaginable: In 1916, more than 200 Austro-Hungarian World War I soldiers lived at 12,000 feet for a year inside Italyâ€™s Marmolada Glacier, in a city of ice tunnels they dug by hand, rationing bread and meat, and, when they could get it, a soft sweet bundt cake called gugelhupf to ease their pain.
Those hidden ice trenches are now the site of another slow battle: Climate change is expected to melt the glacier completely by 2040.
Through thick and thin â€” traversing dangerous mountain passes in winter storms, avalanches, and in the face of climate change â€” lives in the Alps have dependedâ€¦

entry.title: 10 lizards came to Cincinnati in a sock. Now there are thousands.
entry.summary:
A Lazarus lizard suns itself on a warm rock in Burnet Woods, one of many European transplants that have taken over Cincinnati, Ohio. Scientists say the cityâ€™s hills, aging infrastructure, and even its climate have helped them thrive. Native to Europe, common wall lizards are growing bigger, faster, and more resilient in Ohio. Scientists say the city itself may be driving their evolution.
For more than 70 years, thousands of common wall lizards, known as Lazarus lizards, from Europe have made Cincinnati their home. Even through record-low temperatures and snowfall, theyâ€™ve managed to surviveâ€”and multiply. But how did these Mediterranean reptiles gain such a foothold in a Midwestern city? It all started with a 10-year-old boy and a sock full of lizards.
In 1951, George Rau Jr., â€¦
